newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Corporates gear up to change face of Aussie debt.
newsitem.headline: Corporates gear up to change face of Aussie debt.

text.p: The time is ripe for Australian corporations to raise funds in local capital markets as a dwindling supply of government bonds leaves a growing pension funds industry short of investment opportunities.
And analysts say Friday's official interest rate cut to 5.5 percent from 6.0 percent, the fourth cut in under a year, will only encourage them to take the plunge.

"The rate cut will encourage corporate treasurers to issue debt and lock in these rates. Investors will be looking beyond the lower-yielding government debt markets in order to increase returns," said Jason Carley, ANZ Investment Bank's head of research in Sydney.
Analysts see the move to corporate debt revolutionising the local debt market's thinking on investment.

"The significant changes will be for people in the fund managers where you are really going to need to assess credit from a much wider perspective," Matthew Drennan, senior economist at Axiom Funds Management.
"You are going to have to consider 'what credit ratings are we going to let our people invest in'," he added.

This will put increasing demand for research on companies' financial status and put more reliance on credit agencies such as Standard & Poor's Corp and Moody's Investors Service, whose ratings already go hand-in-hand with trading in the U.S. corporate debt market and the Eurobond market.
Until recently, investment fund managers generally only operated in Australian government and state debt markets and usually through taking a punt on the market's next move.

"We are seeing a move away from that to more conservative directional plays in the market, but greater emphasis on taking credit risk or business risk for best return," said Nigel Douglas, chief economist at Merrill Lynch Australia.
The economic climate has also changed markedly from when corporates where last noticeably seen issuing bonds in the early 1990's, when interest rates were still relatively high.

Australian inflation is low -- announcing Friday's rate cut, the RBA said it expected underlying inflation below 2.0 percent in the coming quarters -- yield spreads to government debt of long standing corporate issues have tightened, and the federal and state governments have tightened their fiscal belts.

In last week's federal budget the government said the net borrowing requirement would be negative through to 2000/01, reducing total outstanding debt over that time to some A$84 billion from over A$100 billion.
ANZ Investment Bank, which is a unit of the Melbourne-based big four bank Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, has alredy put in place a research team in Sydney to analyse credit.
The bank's London-based global head of finanical markets, Mark Coombs, was in Sydney on Thursday as part of its commitment to building up interest in the corporate debt market.
Coombs told Reuters Australian investors have been fairly conservative in their approach to credit risk, tending to stick to investments that are in the A-category rated debt.
"It's a new departure for Australian investors. But they are doing the right thing, they are taking their time, they are beginning to understand it professionally," he said.

"We are doing analysis and saying -- look don't mess around in double-A, have a look at triple-B. Start thinking about BBB and the value, and how basically you are getting paid far too much for what is not really that lower credit."
